chapters.title: अध्याय १ - साधन अध्याय
chapters.description: The foundation chapter dealing with the means of knowledge and preliminary concepts

adhikaranams.title: जिज्ञासाधिकरणम्
adhikaranams.samshayam: What is the proper time and qualification for starting the inquiry into Brahman? Is any special preparation needed?
adhikaranams.purvapaksha: Since Brahman is already known through the Vedas, there is no need for systematic inquiry. One can directly proceed to meditation and realization.
adhikaranams.siddhanta: Though Brahman may be mentioned in the Vedas, its true nature requires systematic inquiry through reasoning, scriptural study, and proper understanding. The inquiry should begin after completing the study of dharma (righteous duties) and developing the fourfold qualifications (sadhana chatushtaya).
shankara_additional: Shankara clarifies that 'athah' (now/then) indicates the proper sequence - Brahma inquiry follows dharma inquiry
The inquiry is not merely academic but aimed at liberation from samsara
Proper qualifications include viveka (discrimination), vairagya (dispassion), sama-dama (mental disciplines), and mumukshutva (intense desire for liberation)

adhikaranams.title: जन्माद्यधिकरणम्
adhikaranams.samshayam: What is the definition or nature of Brahman that we are inquiring into?
adhikaranams.purvapaksha: Brahman could be the material cause alone, or the efficient cause alone, or some limited deity who creates the world.
adhikaranams.siddhanta: Brahman is that supreme reality from which the creation, sustenance, and dissolution of this universe proceed. It is both the material and efficient cause of the universe, being of the nature of pure consciousness.
shankara_additional: The word 'janma' includes sthiti (sustenance) and pralaya (dissolution) by the rule of 'janmadyasya'
Brahman is not just any cause, but the intelligent cause, as evidenced by the orderly creation
The universe's emergence from Brahman is not like a pot from clay, but like waves from ocean - non-different in essence

adhikaranams.title: सर्वत्र प्रसिद्धिधिकरणम्
adhikaranams.samshayam: How do we know that the Brahman mentioned in different Upanishads is the same entity?
adhikaranams.purvapaksha: Different Upanishads might be referring to different deities or aspects of divinity, not the same Brahman.
adhikaranams.siddhanta: Brahman is famous (prasiddha) everywhere in all Upanishads as the supreme reality. The consistent description across all scriptures as sat-chit-ananda, the cause of the universe, and the ultimate goal establishes its identity.
shankara_additional: The term 'prasiddhi' indicates not mere fame but established recognition through valid means of knowledge
Apparent differences in descriptions point to different aspects or approaches, not different entities
The unity of Brahman is established through statements like 'sarvam khalvidam brahma' (all this is indeed Brahman)
